docs.lead_paragraph: In a gloomy basement apartment in West Hempstead, N.Y., where sewage pipes snake across the ceiling and the stove must be kept on to warm the chilly air, Cindy Farrar is slowly dying. Ms. Farrar, 48, is suffering from end-stage liver disease and diabetes. Once an intrepid traveler, she has seen her view of the world reduced to a foggy pool of light from a window no larger than the kind at the end of a fast-food drive-through.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; A Sudden Slide Down, Physically and Financially

docs.abstract: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has helped West Hempstead, NY, resident Cindy Farrar, who has end-stage liver disease, pay her bills while she waits for transplant; photo (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND

docs.lead_paragraph: Health Plans Requiring Use Of Mail-Order Pharmacies Employer health plans are requiring consumers to buy widely used drugs like insulin for diabetes or Lipitor for cholesterol by mail order. Employers and the companies that manage prescription drug insurance coverage favor mail-order pharmacies because they can get lucrative rebates and deep discounts from drug makers. Those savings are then shared with employers and health plans. [Page A1.] Lilly Declines on Prozac Report Shares of Eli Lilly fell after reports in a medical journal suggested that the drug company had long concealed evidence that its well-known antidepressant Prozac could cause violent and suicidal behavior. [C2.] A Hotline for Airline Complaints The government set up a hotline for people to call with complaints about flight disruptions over the Christmas holiday weekend. Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta, left, asked the inspector general to look into the snafus at US Airways and Comair, a unit of Delta Air Lines, which grounded 1,100 flights because of a computer problem. [C12.] U.S. Opposes United Pension Deal The government is opposing a deal between United Airlines and its pilots' union on the termination of the pilots' pension plan. [C12.] Europe Cutting Carbon Dioxide Some 12,000 industrial plants across the European Union are facing limits on the amount of carbon dioxide they release, a first step in carrying out the requirements of the Kyoto Climate Protocol. [C2.] F.D.A. Approves Pfizer's Lyrica Pfizer won United States approval to sell its Lyrica pill to treat nerve pain associated with diabetes and shingles. [C2.] Lockheed Wins Air Force Contracts Lockheed Martin has received two Air Force contracts totaling $716 million to continue work on its F/A-22 Raptor fighter jet. [C12.] Delphi Financial Suspends 2 Delphi Financial suspended two employees responsible for a unit's relationship with Marsh & McLennan. [C12.]
